urn:contentItem:6DCV-0SV1-JC5B-G38T-00000-00NY parks employee dies fighting fires; air quality warnings are issued in New York and New Jersey2024-11-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:25:37ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSSTATE AND REGIONALNY parks employee dies fighting fires; air quality warnings are issued in New York and New JerseyPOMPTON LAKES, N.J.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J. (AP) — A New York parks employee died battling one of a number of wildfires in New Jersey and New York amid dry conditions that have prompted air quality warnings in both states, authorities said Sunday.

The worker died when a tree fell on him Saturday afternoon as he battled a major brush fire along the New York-New Jersey border, according to reports from the Eastern Dutchess County Fire and Rescue and the New York state forestry services.

“Rip brother your shift is over job well done,” the New York State forestry services post said.

New York State Police said they were investigating the death amid the fire in Sterling Forest located in Greenwood Lake and identified the victim as Dariel Vasquez, an 18-year-old state Parks and Recreation aide employed by the New York State Parks, Recreation, and Historic Preservation Department.

“Wildland firefighting is a very dangerous profession, and we try to take as many precautions as we can mitigate some of the hazards that are out there in the wildland fire environment. But occasionally accidents do happen,” said Jeremy Oldroyd, forest ranger, New York State Department of Environmental Protection, adding that Vasquez died “assisting with fire line construction.”

The fires in New York and New Jersey come as firefighters are also battling a wildfire in California.

The New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection's Forest Fire Service reported the sprawling blaze had spread to 3.9 square miles (about 10 square kilometers) near the border in Passaic County’s West Milford and Orange County, New York. Officials said Sunday the blaze, dubbed the Jennings Creek wildfire, was now threatening 14 Greenwood Lake structures as well as two New Jersey homes and eight historic buildings in that state's Long Pond Ironworks Historic District. Officials said Saturday afternoon that they did not believe evacutions would be necessary in either state.

Health advisories were issued for parts of New York, including New York City, and northeastern New Jersey due to unhealthy air quality due to smoke from the fires. People were urged to limit strenuous outdoor physical activity if possible; those especially sensitive included the very young and very old and people with ailments such as asthma and heart disease.

New Jersey officials, meanwhile, reported 75 percent containment of a 175-acre (70-hectare) fire in the Pompton Lakes area of Passaic County that was threatening 55 homes, although no evacuations had been ordered.

Progress was also reported on fires in the Bethany Run area on the border of Burlington and Camden counties in Evesham and Voorhees townships; a blaze along the Palisades Interstate Parkway in Englewood Cliffs in Bergen County; and the Pheasant Run wildfire in the Glassboro wildlife protection area of Gloucester County.

Prosecutors in Ocean County on late Saturday afternoon announced arson and firearms charges in connection with a 350-acre (142-hectare) Jackson Township fire that started Wednesday. They said it was sparked by magnesium shards from a shotgun round on the berm of a shooting range. Officials said firing that kind of “incendiary or tracer ammunition” was barred in the state. The majority of the blaze has been contained, officials reported Friday.

In Massachusetts, one wildfire among several fueled by powerful wind gusts and dry leaves burned more than 200 acres in the Lynn Woods Reservation, a municipal park that comprises about 3.4 square miles (8.8 square kilometers) in the city 10 miles (16 kilometers) north of Boston. The Lynn Fire Department cited "a dry spell we have not seen during this time of year in many years.”

Across the county, favorable weather helped fire crews gain more control Sunday over a Southern California wildfire that has destroyed 134 structures and damaged dozens more.

Crews increased containment of the Mountain Fire to 26% in Ventura County northwest of Los Angeles. The fire’s size remains around 32 square miles (about 83 square kilometers). The cause is under investigation.

“The fire continues to creep and smolder in steep rugged terrain. Threats remain to critical infrastructure, highways, and communities,” according to the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection, better known as Cal Fire.

The fire broke out Wednesday and exploded in size with the arrival of dry, warm and gusty Santa Ana winds, forcing thousands of residents to flee suburban neighborhoods and agricultural areas near the city of Camarillo.

Crews increased containment of the Mountain Fire to 26% in Ventura County northwest of Los Angeles. The fire’s size remains around 32 square miles (about 83 square kilometers). The cause is under investigation.

“The fire continues to creep and smolder in steep rugged terrain. Threats remain to critical infrastructure, highways, and communities,” according to the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection, better known as Cal Fire.

The fire broke out Wednesday and exploded in size with the arrival of dry, warm and gusty Santa Ana winds, forcing thousands of residents to flee suburban neighborhoods and agricultural areas near the city of Camarillo.

urn:contentItem:6DCY-HJV1-JCMC-W0WN-00000-00N.Y. parks employee dies fighting fires; air quality warnings issued in New York, New Jersey2024-11-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:25:37ZLexisNexisUS NEWSN.Y. parks employee dies fighting fires; air quality warnings issued in New York, New JerseyBy Associated Press

POMPTON LAKES, N.J. - A New York parks employee died battling one of a number of wildfires in New Jersey and New York amid dry conditions that have prompted air quality warnings in both states, authorities said Sunday.

The worker died when a tree fell on him Saturday afternoon as he battled a major brush fire along the New York-New Jersey border, according to reports from the Eastern Dutchess County Fire and Rescue and the New York state forestry services.

"Rip brother your shift is over job well done," the New York State forestry services post said.

New York State Police said they were investigating the death amid the fire in Sterling Forest located in Greenwood Lake and identified the victim as Dariel Vasquez, an 18-year-old state Parks and Recreation aide employed by the New York State Parks, Recreation, and Historic Preservation Department.

The fires in New York and New Jersey come as firefighters are also battling a wildfire in California.

The New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection's Forest Fire Service reported the sprawling blaze had spread to 3.9 square miles (about 10 square kilometers) near the border in Passaic County's West Milford and Orange County, New York. Officials said Sunday the blaze, dubbed the Jennings Creek wildfire, was now threatening 14 Greenwood Lake structures as well as two New Jersey homes and eight buildings in that state's Long Pond Ironworks Historic District.

Health advisories were issued for parts of New York, including New York City, and northeastern New Jersey due to unhealthy air quality due to smoke from the fires. People were urged to limit strenuous outdoor physical activity if possible; those especially sensitive included the very young and very old and people with ailments such as asthma and heart disease.

New Jersey officials, meanwhile, reported 75 percent containment of a 175-acre fire in the Pompton Lakes area of Passaic County that was threatening 55 homes, although no evacuations had been ordered.

Progress was also reported on fires in the Bethany Run area on the border of Burlington and Camden counties in Evesham and Voorhees townships; a blaze along the Palisades Interstate Parkway in Englewood Cliffs in Bergen County; and the Pheasant Run wildfire in the Glassboro wildlife protection area of Gloucester County.

Prosecutors in Ocean County on late Saturday afternoon announced arson and firearms charges in connection with a 350-acre Jackson Township fire that started Wednesday. They said it was sparked by magnesium shards from a shotgun round on the berm of a shooting range. Officials said firing that kind of "incendiary or tracer ammunition" was barred in the state. The majority of the blaze has been contained, officials reported Friday.

In Massachusetts, one wildfire among several fueled by powerful wind gusts and dry leaves burned more than 200 acres in the Lynn Woods Reservation, a municipal park that comprises about 3.4 square miles in the city 10 miles north of Boston.

"This is a dry spell we have not seen during this time of year in many years," the Lynn Fire Department said in a statement on social media as firefighters continued to battle the blaze, blaming its intensely on low humidity as well as winds and dry leaves on the ground.

It was one of many brush fires that cropped up across the region. In Foxborough, fire crews said that containing a wildfire at the F. Gilbert Hills State Forest would be a "a multi-day event."

Wind gusts topped 40 mph on Saturday, and less-powerful gusts continued Sunday.

Firefighters and forest agencies warned against outdoor burning.

The drier-than-normal weather is expected to continue, and virtually all of New England is categorized as being in drought or being abnormally dry. Most of the region was expected to see some light rain Sunday night, but there are no large rainfall events in the forecast, said National Weather Service meteorologist Jerry Combs.

Firefighters in California were also battling a scattering of blazes over the weekend, including one north of Los Angeles that had burned more than 100 structures.

Evacuation orders were downgraded to warnings for residents in several areas of Ventura County, where the Mountain Fire held at around 32 square miles and was 26% contained, authorities said.

urn:contentItem:6DCV-0M01-JC5B-G38P-00000-00NY parks employee dies fighting fires; air quality warnings are issued in New York and New Jersey2024-11-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:25:37ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSSTATE AND REGIONALNY parks employee dies fighting fires; air quality warnings are issued in New York and New JerseyPOMPTON LAKES, N.J.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J. (AP) — A New York parks employee died battling one of a number of wildfires in New Jersey and New York amid dry conditions that have prompted air quality warnings in both states, authorities said Sunday.

The worker died when a tree fell on him Saturday afternoon as he battled a major brush fire along the New York-New Jersey border, according to reports from the Eastern Dutchess County Fire and Rescue and the New York state forestry services.

“Rip brother your shift is over job well done,” the New York State forestry services post said.

New York State Police said they were investigating the death amid the fire in Sterling Forest located in Greenwood Lake and identified the victim as Dariel Vasquez, an 18-year-old state Parks and Recreation aide employed by the New York State Parks, Recreation, and Historic Preservation Department.

“Wildland firefighting is a very dangerous profession, and we try to take as many precautions as we can mitigate some of the hazards that are out there in the wildland fire environment. But occasionally accidents do happen,” said Jeremy Oldroyd, forest ranger, New York State Department of Environmental Protection, adding that Vasquez died “assisting with fire line construction.”

The fires in New York and New Jersey come as firefighters are also battling a wildfire in California.

The New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection's Forest Fire Service reported the sprawling blaze had spread to 3.9 square miles (about 10 square kilometers) near the border in Passaic County’s West Milford and Orange County, New York. Officials said Sunday the blaze, dubbed the Jennings Creek wildfire, was now threatening 14 Greenwood Lake structures as well as two New Jersey homes and eight historic buildings in that state's Long Pond Ironworks Historic District. Officials said Saturday afternoon that they did not believe evacutions would be necessary in either state.

Health advisories were issued for parts of New York, including New York City, and northeastern New Jersey due to unhealthy air quality due to smoke from the fires. People were urged to limit strenuous outdoor physical activity if possible; those especially sensitive included the very young and very old and people with ailments such as asthma and heart disease.

New Jersey officials, meanwhile, reported 75 percent containment of a 175-acre (70-hectare) fire in the Pompton Lakes area of Passaic County that was threatening 55 homes, although no evacuations had been ordered.

Progress was also reported on fires in the Bethany Run area on the border of Burlington and Camden counties in Evesham and Voorhees townships; a blaze along the Palisades Interstate Parkway in Englewood Cliffs in Bergen County; and the Pheasant Run wildfire in the Glassboro wildlife protection area of Gloucester County.

Prosecutors in Ocean County on late Saturday afternoon announced arson and firearms charges in connection with a 350-acre (142-hectare) Jackson Township fire that started Wednesday. They said it was sparked by magnesium shards from a shotgun round on the berm of a shooting range. Officials said firing that kind of “incendiary or tracer ammunition” was barred in the state. The majority of the blaze has been contained, officials reported Friday.

In Massachusetts, one wildfire among several fueled by powerful wind gusts and dry leaves burned more than 200 acres in the Lynn Woods Reservation, a municipal park that comprises about 3.4 square miles (8.8 square kilometers) in the city 10 miles (16 kilometers) north of Boston. The Lynn Fire Department cited "a dry spell we have not seen during this time of year in many years.”

Across the county, favorable weather helped fire crews gain more control Sunday over a Southern California wildfire that has destroyed 134 structures and damaged dozens more.

Crews increased containment of the Mountain Fire to 26% in Ventura County northwest of Los Angeles. The fire’s size remains around 32 square miles (about 83 square kilometers). The cause is under investigation.

“The fire continues to creep and smolder in steep rugged terrain. Threats remain to critical infrastructure, highways, and communities,” according to the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection, better known as Cal Fire.

The fire broke out Wednesday and exploded in size with the arrival of dry, warm and gusty Santa Ana winds, forcing thousands of residents to flee suburban neighborhoods and agricultural areas near the city of Camarillo.

urn:contentItem:6BMT-B0N1-DY7R-R1J1-00000-00Research from Nanjing Forestry University Has Provided New Study Findings on Algorithms (Research on a Real-Time Monitoring System for Campus Woodland Fires via Deep Learning)2024-03-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:25:37ZLexisNexisALGORITHMSResearch from Nanjing Forestry University Has Provided New Study Findings on Algorithms (Research on a Real-Time Monitoring System for Campus Woodland Fires via Deep Learning)


2024 MAR 25 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Math Daily News -- Data detailed on algorithms have been presented. According to news originating from Nanjing, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "To solve the problems of low recognition accuracy and large amounts of computation required in forest fire detection algorithms, this paper, aiming to make improvements in these two aspects, proposes a G-YOLOv5n-CB forest fire detection algorithm based on the YOLOv5 algorithm and develops a set of real-time fire monitoring systems applicable to campus forest land with the aid of deep learning technology."


Financial supporters for this research include 2023 Jiangsu Higher Education Teaching Reform Research Project.
Our news reporters obtained a quote from the research from Nanjing Forestry University: "The system employs an unmanned vehicle to navigate automatically and collect image information through a camera and deploys its algorithm on the unmanned vehicle's Jetson Nano hardware platform. The results demonstrate that the proposed YOLOv5n-CB algorithm increased the mAP value index by 1.4% compared with the original algorithm on the self-made forest fire dataset."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "The improved G-YOLOv5n-CB model was deployed on the Jetson Nano platform for testing, and its detection speed reached 15 FPS. It can accurately detect and display real-time forest fires on campus and has, thus, a high application value."
For more information on this research see: Research on a Real-Time Monitoring System for Campus Woodland Fires via Deep Learning. Forests, 2024,15(3). (Forests - http://www.mdpi.com/journal/forests/). The publisher for Forests is MDPI AG.

urn:contentItem:6FGN-B273-RT00-52C4-00000-00White House Moves to Reset Global Trade, Boost U.S. Workers; ICE Agent in Contempt of Court Over Boston Arrest; Tomorrow, Democratic Coalition Visiting Southern Border; Hearing Over Alleged Gang Member Deportations; DOGE Team Details Social Security Fraud Uncovered; Trump Elections Order Met With Democrat Resistance2025-04-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:25:37ZLexisNexisTHE STORY WITH MARTHA MACCALLUM3:00 PM ESTKevin Hassett, Michael Shellenberger040301cb.263White House Moves to Reset Global Trade, Boost U.S. Workers; ICE Agent in Contempt of Court Over Boston Arrest; Tomorrow, Democratic Coalition Visiting Southern Border; Hearing Over Alleged Gang Member Deportations; DOGE Team Details Social Security Fraud Uncovered; Trump Elections Order Met With Democrat ResistanceMartha MacCallum, Peter Doocy, Kellyanne Conway, Bill Melugin, Andy McCarthy, Kerri Urbahn, Bret Baier

MARTHA MACCALLUM, FOX NEWS ANCHOR: Right you are, John. Thank you very much. Good afternoon everybody. I'm Martha MacCallum. And breaking right now on The Story, we will be speaking in moments with one of the president's top economic advisers and get his thoughts on what's going on in the markets, what world leaders are saying in response to all of this, as well as everyday Americans reacting to his sweeping liberation day tariffs.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

J.D. VANCE, U.S. VICE PRESIDENT: This is a big change. I'm not going to shy away from it, but we needed a big change, Lawrence. We cannot keep going down the Joe Biden globalist pathway where we have $2 trillion of peacetime debt and deficits. We have manufacturing disappearing. That is not working for Americans.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACCALLUM: Well, that pretty much says it from the vice president. That is what this is all about. It is a bold move and we're seeing a bold reaction in the markets, but many say that is to be expected. Many feel like it's a gut punch, but that it's a necessary one. And the president clearly feels that it will make the country stronger in the long run.

We're going to lay all of this out for you this hour as we dive into all of it with National Economic Council Director Kevin Hassett on the economics, Kellyanne Conway on the politics and what this will mean for you.

We kick things off with Senior White House Correspondent Peter Doocy and some brand new remarks as we sort of go through day one of this new liberation reality in terms of how it all works from President Trump, as Peter joins us from the South Lawn. Hi, Peter.

PETER DOOCY, FOX NEWS SENIOR WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT: Martha, good afternoon. I just talked to President Trump within the last 15 minutes or so and he explained why it is he does not think all of this red on Wall Street today is a reason to panic.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DOOCY: The markets today are way down, the worst day of the year because of the tariffs. So, how's it going?

DONALD TRUMP, U.S. PRESIDENT: I think it's going very well. It was an operation, like when a patient gets operated on and it's a big thing. I said this would exactly be the way it is. We have $6 or $7 trillion coming into our country and we've never seen anything like it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOOCY: There's a new flat 10 percent tariff on trading partners, and then the White House has calculated additional tariffs based on what other countries are charging us, 34 percent on China, 20 percent on the E.U., 46 percent on Vietnam, 32 percent on Taiwan, 24 percent on Japan. You can see on the screen. They're not going to go any higher because President Trump is now saying that -- you just heard it there, that the operation is over, the patient survived. But allies are still completely freaked out.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

URSULA VON DER LEYEN, EUROPEAN COMMISSION PRESIDENT: The global economy will massively suffer. Uncertainty will spiral and trigger the rise of further protectionism. The consequences will be dire for millions of people around the globe.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOOCY: Here in D.C., Democratic lawmakers are warning about a recession, but at the moment, they're not offering an alternative economic vision except for the status quo. Martha?

MACCALLUM: All right. Peter, thank you very much. So, on Capitol Hill, plenty of hair on fire reaction to the tariffs so far. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. PETER WELCH (D-VT): The tariffs are a catastrophe. There's no intellectual basis to them.

SEN. TIM KAINE (D-VA): And they're going to stand by, as you know, the president pushes our economy into a recession.

SEN. CHUCK SCHUMER (D-NY): Trump has single-handedly created a financial forest fire.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACCALLUM: Okay. Let's take a listen to some everyday folks, a retired auto worker and a Pennsylvania man who says that this has been a long time coming for the blue collar communities that have been hollowed out, the forgotten men and women that we heard so much about in the first term as they felt left behind.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BRIAN PANNEBECKER, RETIRED AUTO WORKER: My entire life, I have watched plant after plant after plant in Detroit and in the metro Detroit area close.

Donald Trump's policies are going to bring product back into those underutilized plants.

From where we are in Pennsylvania to Wisconsin to Michigan, when the auto worker was there and said, you know, I have seen over my lifetime every factory, every plant, every mill closed down.

It was complete music to our ears out here because we live in this wasteland.

At some point, somebody needs to speak up for us, and this is why we voted for Donald Trump, full stop.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACCALLUM: Interesting. Let's bring in Kellyanne Conway, former senior counselor to President Trump, now president of KAC Consulting. Kellyanne, it's always good to have you with us.

You know, when I listen to that man, I think about traveling around the country during election year and you think about the towns in upstate New York, in New Hampshire, in Pennsylvania, across this country where you see shut down factories. A lot of them turned into, you know, maybe a coffee shop or a town rec center, but they are not producing jobs. And this has been on the president's mind since at least 1988. You can substitute China for Japan here, but let's watch this at home.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: You can call it a tax, you can call it whatever you want to call it, but those countries should be paying us major billions of dollars.

And I think a lot of people are tired of watching other countries ripping off the United States. Behind our backs, they laugh at us because of our own stupidity. We let Japan come in and dump everything right into our markets and everything. It's not free trade.

I do get tired of seeing the country rip us.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACCALLUM: So, now in his second term, Kellyanne, he is swinging for the fences with all of this.

KELLYANNE CONWAY, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: That's why no one should be surprised, Martha. This is President Trump, who is echoing much of what he did and wanted to do even more of in his first term and completing that transaction out. We are seeing some positive reaction today. For all the negative Debbie Downers, look at the positive reaction. Stellantis, which owns Chrysler and Ram and Jeep, they came out today and they said that they are going to stop producing in Mexico. They're one of the ones that are the big manufacturers in Mexico, they're going to stop doing that. You've got Ford saying they're going to start producing more in Indiana in the U.S. of A. And now, just today, they're offering the same price to we the people, to consumers for their vehicles that they offer to their own employees.

India came out today, they got hit pretty hard yesterday with these tariffs, and they said, we are looking forward to talking about bilateral trade deals. Remember, these tariffs are a down payment to getting those kind of bilateral trade deals in the first term President Trump in quick order, make great trade deals with Japan, with Mexico and Canada, with Korea and even with China. He was on his way to do that with the E.U. when COVID hit. So, that was interrupted. But, geez, the Chinese were in the east room of the White House, Martha, in mid-January 2020 signing a written, verifiable, enforceable, granular phase one trade deal. So, this will do that.

And, look, for everybody saying tariffs are attacks, I think you have to look at them more as the old sanctions. The president is trying to compel or incentivize transformative generational changes in behavior by companies, by categories, by countries, by collections of countries, E.U., I'm looking at you, and so that we're no longer taking advantage of.

Last point, Martha, the president, gave two statistics yesterday I want everyone to hear. He said, by the time Biden left, we had a $1.2 trillion trade deficit, historic high, and we had led 1 million manufacturing jobs. So, those men and women that feel invisible, feel forgotten, feel abandoned by their government, by the C-suite of America many times, they're counting on this president to make it right for them. They're not going to go back to college and get in our history degree at 50 to support themselves and their families. They want to stay as the fourth, fifth generation steel worker, auto manufacturer in these states, which, by the way, President Trump won this last time in large part because of these promises.

MACCALLUM: Yes. This is David Sanger in The New York Times today. Trump's tariffs are the latest sign of his second term appetite for risk. People around Mr. Trump say that the legal, electoral and psychological restraints that bound him in the past are gone. After he escaped death by an assassin's bullet, he took it as a sign that he was spared in order to complete his vision of what America should look like.

Give us your sense. You have known him and worked with him a long time. Is that, in your mind, an accurate description of where the president is in this moment right now?

CONWAY: Sanger is spot on. That's like having a conversation with President Trump over the last few months, if not year. It's absolutely true, Martha. Look, we all believe in second chances, but who has ever gotten his large as second chance as President Donald J. Trump to come back after so many critics and members of the resistance were trying to put him in the big house and prevent him from never again being in the White House? He has this second chance. He's working with a volume and velocity.

You know what's fascinating? He's not out on the road. Eight years ago, we were in Michigan. We were at the dairy manufacturer in Wisconsin. We were at the ball bearing manufacturer in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania, just a couple trips. I remember taking with him, he's at the White House because people are coming to him. And they are saying, here is the investment we're making in America. And this White House is highlighting a lot of those positive investments.

So, what Sanger says is correct, but also President Trump is heralding and lauding. He did it recently with Johnson & Johnson. He's talking about what Intel just did, what open A.I. and Stargate are doing. So, he is also saying if you -- tariffs are your choice, not his.

If you want better reciprocal, balanced trade deals, that's what we want. He'll say a tariff is your choice, because if you make more in the USA, you're going to take advantage of low corporate tax rates, and he has said that his team will give you blue chip, white glove treatment if you invest $1 billion here, they'll accelerate the permitting and approval processes.

MACCALLUM: Yes, that there are clearly opportunities for companies that want to take advantage of them. And, you know, in closing, one of the things that I find so interesting is the battle of his first term was sort of a, you know, legal FBI attacks going against him and different elements of behavior, and we all walked down that road, we know what I'm talking about. This time, the battle is over policy that is being enacted as we watch it all play out. And I think it's probably his opportunity to get these things done when he got pulled away from that track by so much of that distraction in the first term.

Kellyanne, thank you so much.

CONWAY: Well said, Martha.

MACCALLUM: Always good to have you with us.

CONWAY: This is a long-term play. Thank you.

MACCALLUM: Thank you.

So, coming up, we're going to dig deeper into this with White House Economic Adviser Kevin Hassett. He's here next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: In terms of tariffs, it think it's interesting to note that the average U.S. MFN tariff on Chinese goods coming into the United States is 2 percent, whereas the average Chinese MFN tariff on U.S. goods going into China is 35 percent. Is that reciprocal?

In terms of jobs, this is the biggest and cruelest hoax of all. The China trade supports 170,000 jobs in the United States, 170,000 jobs, whereas our imports from China support 10 million jobs at least.

The fact is that U.S.-China trade is a job loser.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACCALLUM: Wow. Good point, Nancy. That is an interesting contrast to the Democrat criticism of today for President Trump's global tariffs, which have only been in effect for, you know, not even 24 hours, but they've decided that it's an idea that should be dead on arrival. But Nancy Pelosi office had thought it made a lot of sense back in the 1990s.

Kevin Hassett is director of the National Economic Council. He joins me now. Kevin, great to have you with us.

KEVIN HASSETT, DIRECTOR, NATIONAL ECONOMIC COUNCIL: It's great to be here.

MACCALLUM: Your reaction to that -- thank you. Your reaction to that market down? I think it's at as low of the day down, about 1,500 for what that is worth in the mix here. What would you -- what are you talking about in the White House? Is there any panic about what's happening at this point or what is the general feeling about what people should know about this?

HASSETT: Sure. What people should know about this is that President Trump ran on this because he has a positive vision of a Golden Age of America where the jobs come back. The jobs that formerly sensible Speaker Pelosi talked about just now.

The fact is that if you go back to 2000, when China entered the World Trade Organization, everybody said, oh, it's going to be so good for everybody's welfare because prices are going to come down. We're going to get all these cheap Chinese goods. And then, what happened for two terms of the Bush administration, two terms of the Obama administration, is that real incomes stagnated. Over the whole 15 years, starting in 2000, real incomes only went up by $80 over the whole time, or, you know, a little more than $5 a year.

And so, while everybody's telling us, oh, your standard of living is going to go up so much because of these lower prices of the Chinese goods, that it didn't happen for the typical median person, and the reason is that wages suffered so much, right?

So, if prices are going down and wages are going down, then you don't get real wage growth. And that happened, really, for 15 years after China entered the WTO. And that's what we're talking about for the average person, Martha. If you think about the people who are in the communities that were most affected, it was way, way worse than for the average person.

MACCALLUM: So, let me ask you, Kevin --

HASSETT: And President Trump was elected to fix that, and that's what he's doing.

MACCALLUM: So, I want to show this tweet by hedge fund billionaire Bill Ackman, who used to support a lot of Democrats. But during the election he has switched over. Listen to what President Trump had to say and begin to side with him. He says, sometimes the best strategy in a negotiation is convincing the other side that you're crazy.

Do you think that's true here? And there's been a lot of discussion, oh, there's going to be no negotiations at Howard Lutnick, he's standing firm on all of this. And then, it feels certainly like there is some negotiation going on. Is there or isn't there?

HASSETT: There's nothing crazy about this policy. In fact, this is a policy that was tried and was effective in the United States for 150 years. And in fact, I think the first law passed in the US or one of the first laws was a tariff.

And so, this is a tried-and-true strategy. And you know, I absolutely do not think there's anything crazy about it. The president did write the book, The Art of the Deal, but he's going to decide when and if there's going to be deals on this.

But as we set the reciprocal tariffs and we look at the misbehavior of foreign countries that are basically dumping their products and hurting American workers, then a lot of the policies that we looked at are things that we think they're probably not going to change.

And so, I think the E.U., for example, is an economy that's really on the ropes and it's on the ropes because of all the terrible things that the E.U. regulators and taxers are doing. And I don't think they're going to change policy much because of what we've done. And if that's true, then the tariff on E.U. is going to stay the same.

MACCALLUM: That's interesting.

HASSETT: But if they do come back and they come make a deal with the president, of course he'll listen, because what he cares about is the American worker and the welfare of the American people.

MACCALLUM: I mean, if we drop regulations, that's one of the things -- this is one of the non-tariff issues that impacts the economies of all these other countries. They have other built-in costs. And if we can drop regulations in this country, lower tax, and make it easier for manufacturers to open up new shop here, that could have a very positive impact.

But it's interesting, The Wall Street Journal raising this point, when you look at these country-by-country tariffs and asking, if we want to discourage other countries to produce outside of China, and that's the United States, of course, but also places like Vietnam, why does Vietnam have a 46 percent tariff and Israel has a 17 percent tariff?

Can you explain, Kevin?

HASSETT: Right. Well, the issue that came out, right, is that the president judged that it's a national emergency, that our trade deficit is making it so that we're dependent on so much thing that we can't produce at home, like antibiotics and so on.

And so, what happened was that the U.S. trade representative looked at where the trade deficits were and adjusted the tariffs in order to respond to the national emergency that I think we all agree about. And so, I think that the fact is that a lot of goods are transshipped through other Asian economies from China and that the tariffs on China were I guess offset somewhat by pushing the trade around to other countries that didn't really pay attention to where the stuff was coming from.

And so, those trans shippers are probably regretting the fact that they made the deal with China to do that. And, you know, I think right now the tariff that they're facing is an appropriate response to what they were doing to destroy American jobs.

MACCALLUM: I got to ask you a question because you brought it up in a little bit in your answer there with pharmaceuticals because we heard during COVID how much was produced in China. And do you have any concern that China is going to cut off supplies to our pharmaceuticals as a backlash to this?

HASSETT: I think that, of course, they wouldn't. I believe anyone believes that they would be foolish enough to do that. There are lots of other places to get pharmaceuticals. The problem is there aren't a lot of pharmaceutical plants here in the U.S. and that's why we have this policy to fix that. And so, no, I don't think people need to be worried about that. But -- and I don't think that they would do that.

MACCALLUM: Real quick, if you can. You know, people look at this and say, great, we'd love to see more manufacturing in the United States. What -- give it timeframe? How long is it going to take? Because I've seen factories that take five years to get up and running. How quickly can that happen?

HASSETT: Well, it's already happening. If you look at the real-time data from last month or the month before or two months ago, then you can start to see that people are beginning to get ready. Like there were a whole bunch of jobs, auto jobs created in the last jobs reported.

So, the fact is that people are starting to onshore production here in the U.S. and it's very visible in the hard data. What's not so visible is what's going on in the survey data. So, there was a lot of survey things coming out saying people are anxious about the change, and that's a normal response to change. But the hard data that we've been looking at was positive.

MACCALLUM: OK. We need to give this a few weeks and maybe a few months to really watch this shake out. The market obviously having a big reaction today, but I noticed it keeps sort of bouncing off around the same point and pulling back a little bit higher. So, we'll see if that's the bottom for today. Kevin, thank you. Always great to have you with us.

HASSETT: Good to see you.

MACCALLUM: Kevin Hassett joining us here on The Story.

So, why Democrats are heading down to the border tomorrow, not too much of this in the prior administration, but today a whole bunch of senators are going to have decided to head down to the border. We'll show you what's going on there, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACCALLUM: Big legal battle playing out in Boston where an ICE agent is now in contempt of court after arresting this man as he was in the middle of his own criminal trial. He is in the United States illegally. And on the other side of the country, a coalition of Democrats visiting the southern border tomorrow as numbers there continue to plummet. Now, they have decided time to hit the border.

National Correspondent Bill Melugin reporting live from Los Angeles. Hi, Bill.

BILL MELUGIN, FOX NEWS NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT: Hey, Martha. Good afternoon to you.

Well, Democrats apparently have a newly found interest in the southern border as a group of them are going to be visiting the San Diego border tomorrow, they say, to conduct oversight on the Trump administration's border policies.

It's unclear exactly where that oversight was during the last four years under President Biden when illegal crossings surged to the highest levels in recorded history several years in a row. But when House Democrats arrived to the border tomorrow, they're not likely to see much of anything down there as illegal crossings last month plummeted to the lowest levels in modern history, and the border is effectively locked down now under President Trump.

Mississippi Congressman Bennie Thompson, the ranking member of the House Homeland Security Committee, is going to lead that delegation with a handful of other Democrats. You might remember when we tried to ask Thompson about the border on Capitol Hill in late 2022, he didn't have a whole lot to say.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MELUGIN: In your opinion, is the border secure?

REP. BENNIE THOMPSON (D-MS): I have to go give a speech. Did you hear me?

MELUGIN: I heard you. It's a quick question. Is the border secure?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MELUGIN: In the meantime, in Boston, the U.S. attorney in Massachusetts is now threatening the local Boston district attorney with felony charges for saying he might charge an ICE agent for arresting an illegal alien during his criminal trial. In a letter obtained by the Boston Herald, U.S. Attorney Leah Foley writes, in part, any attempt or threat to interfere with the lawful actions of federal government agents will not be tolerated. It is a felony offense to assault, resist, oppose, impede, intimidate, or interfere with an immigration officer's efforts to duly execute the immigration laws of the United States.

And, Martha, I didn't stop there. That U.S. attorney also sent a letter to the Boston judge who initially held that ICE officer in contempt of court for arresting that alien. She told the judge that he has zero jurisdiction to do such a thing under the supremacy clause of the U.S. Constitution. I'll send it back to you.

MACCALLUM: Amazing. Bill, thank you very much. So, we're going to have the latest for you from a federal court hearing in Washington about that deportation flight, those flights, we should say, at this point of alleged terrorist gang members to El Salvador as the White House rips Democrats for misguided outrage on President Trump's migrant crackdown.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

VANCE: This is such a weird, mistaken placement of priorities. We need to make our country stronger. We need to create jobs. We need to make our streets safer. What is it about congressional Democrats that get more angry at deporting violent gang members than they do at the victims of those violent gang members? I don't even understand where they're coming from.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACCALLUM: So right now, Judge James Boasberg, a name that has become pretty familiar to most people across the country by now, admonishing the Trump Department of Justice, as they appear before him in federal court today. He wants them to prove that the administration did not defy his order to turn those planes around when they deported more than 100 alleged gang members using the Alien Enemies Act.

He has warned that there will be consequences if the order was violated, and said that he thinks they "acted in bad faith." We just heard that moments ago. So meanwhile, the administration is asking the Supreme Court to step in and to lift the deportation block.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JD VANCE, VICE PRESIDENT OF UNITED STATES: Some radical left judges have stepped in and said you're not allowed to deport MS-13 gang members. That's crazy. We think the Supreme Court's going to overrule it and we're going to keep on fighting for the President's prerogative to enforce the law.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACCALLUM: All right. Let's bring in Andy McCarthy, former federal prosecutor and FOX News contributor. And Kerri Urbahn, FOX News legal editor. Andy, let me start with you.

It's interesting that they have continued these flights. I believe another plane went earlier this week to El Salvador, except that the State Department is saying that they did not remove them under the Alien Enemies Act this time. They did it using the traditional, I'm sorry, the traditional legal authority to enforce immigration laws, which is pretty much what you said they should have done in the first round, right?

ANDY MCCARTHY, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Well, you know, it's also more so what Judge Boasberg has said. I don't think, you know, Boasberg is a left of center guy, but I think he's a -- he's not a bad judge and he's certainly not a lunatic. And one of the things he said was that since in either event, you would have to prove to some level of satisfaction that these guys are members of Tren de Aragua.

If you do it under the ordinary immigration laws, the administration has already labeled them or designated Tren de Aragua as a foreign terrorist organization.

MACCALLUM: Right.

MCCARTHY: So that would be unimpeachable. Whereas the Alien Enemies Act, I think has a lot of legal hurdles and complications that may be problematic.

MACCALLUM: So, Kerri, you know, the order that is being discussed right now is whether or not he defied them, whether or not the Trump White House and the DOJ defied the order of this judge. It's not really about the underlying question of whether or not removing these suspected TDA individuals violated, you know, was a misuse of that law.

KERRI URBAHN, FOX NEWS LEGAL EDITOR: Yes, that's right. And I think this is going to come down to the oral order versus the written order. And I would have to say, I know that Andy disagrees with me, but I'm going to go via the Mark Levin school of thought on this and go back to the case that he litigated in 2003, which is the district, the D.C. District here, federal court that Judge Brosberg is presiding over.

That says that underscores the need for a written order, that an injunction is an injunction when it's written. And the reason this matters is because the fight really comes down to when Judge Boasberg verbally directed them to turn those planes around. He then gave them a break. I think he thought they were going to go make a phone call and interrupt this national security operation.

Apparently they didn't. They waited for the written order and at that point those planes were long gone. DOJ is doubling down on this written aspect and saying, look, we didn't defy anything because your written order came right after we already did this. And, so it'll be interesting to see where they land on all this.

I will say I think Judge Boasberg is pretty determined, though, to find them in violation of this order. So I don't see much hope for them with him.

MACCALLUM: Yes. He's, you know, saying things like I can't believe you acted the way you did in this court hearing right now. So he's clearly ticked off that he thinks that the planes may have not left by the time he put this order down. JD Vance, the Vice president basically says we're not going to ask for permission. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

VANCE: We do not ask permission from far left Democrats before we deport illegal immigrants. We do the American people's business. And again, for the American people who are watching, this is such a weird, mistaken placement of priorities.

We need to make our country stronger. We need to create jobs. We need to make our streets safer.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACCALLUM: Andy, your reaction to that?

MCCARTHY: Well, I just think, you know, the politics is overwhelming the law here. No one is saying they can't deport these people. Nobody is saying that. But in the United States, we have due process of law, right?

When I prosecuted foreign terrorists who all in the ended up, well, most of them getting life sentences, I couldn't say to the agent, go arrest him and instead of bringing him to court, put him on a plane and take him to a third country. You know, we have laws about how, you know, the process that you have to go through in order to obtain that outcome.

And there's two things the courts are very clear on here. One is, the courts are going to defer to the political branches about who gets to be in this country and who doesn't get to be in this country. They're going to have a lot of running room on that. But you have to comply with the due process. They're very clear on that.

MACCALLUM: So, Kerri, in your has the DOJ now decided that they're going to go at this a slightly different way, as Andy in part suggests there, and remove these people under the law that says, you know, they're illegal, they're part of a terrorist organization and they believe they can substantiate that.

And since their country doesn't want them back, we're sending them to El Salvador under agreement with that country.

URBAHN: Well, I think they already have adjusted temporarily in the meantime, which we saw with them deporting those folks under the normal traditional immigration laws. Look, I think their strategy up until this point with respect to immigration is, let's throw everything at the wall and see what sticks. It's what we're seeing with birthright citizenship.

I mean, they've lost all of that so far, but they knew that going in because they're just trying to get that issue before the Supreme Court. With respect to the Alien Enemies Act, I think the reason they did it was because it's fast and it doesn't require the same exact process as -- or really the same process at all as these other laws require. But it does,, to Andy's point, require something. So what is that something exactly?

And I think, you know, look, I think the Trump administration is, in some ways, again, seeing what works. And maybe they'll pull back as it doesn't. But in the meantime, I think they're dealing with a pretty frustrated judge.

MACCALLUM: Yes. I think that they have decided politically that they want to fulfill the promises that were made --

URBAHN: That's right.

MACCALLUM: -- on the campaign trail and they're going to keep doing that. I think it's a basic theory of it's easier to ask forgiveness than permission at this point. And they're plowing forward and they're hoping, as Kerri says, that some of these things that end up in the Supreme Court and they'll see what happens then.

Kerri and Andy, thank you both so much. Always good to see you.

MCCARTHY: Thank you.

URBAHN: Thank you.

MACCALLUM: So coming up, Governor Tim Walz making things personal in his battle with Elon Musk. More on that, brand new stuff next.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TIM WALZ, MINNESOTA GOVERNOR: Look, this -- it's not personal with him. It's a little bit personal. I don't want to be disingenuous. The guy does bother me, it's a little bit personal.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACCALLUM: And JD Vance reveals what's next for the leader of DOGE.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

VANCE: People don't realize how vast and uncontrolled the bureaucracy was. We've started to chip away at it but there's a lot of work to do.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACCALLUM: So more of Vice President Vance in the interview this morning, doubling down on the White House's denial of reporting that Elon Musk will be stepping back in the next few weeks.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

VANCE: The work of Elon is not even close to done. You look at all of the fraudulent grants that they found, you look at people who are 150 years old who are fraudulently collecting Social Security payments. You see our Social Security system, 40 percent of the people who are calling in are actually committing fraud. That means the 60 percent who need their Social Security checks are waiting in line. DOGE has got a lot of work to do.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACCALLUM: So Bret Baier heard quite a bit from the Doge team last week on the issues that it is seeing in the Social Security system.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ARAM MOGHADDASSI, DOGE ENGINEER: When you want to change your bank account, you can call Social Security. We learned 40 percent of the phone calls that they get are from fraudsters.

STEVE DAVIS, DOGE CHIEF OPERATING OFFICER: There are over 15 million people that are over the age of 120 that are marked as alive in the Social Security system.

ELON MUSK, HEAD, DOGE: Ninety-four -year-old grandmother is actually as a result of DOGE'S work going to get her check. She's not going to be robbed by fraudsters like she's getting robbed today.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACCALLUM: Let's bring in Bret Baier, FOX News chief political anchor and executive editor and anchor of "Special Report." Bret, great to have you with us today.

BRET BAIER, FOX NEWS CHIEF POLITICAL ANCHOR: Hey, Martha.

MACCALLUM: I assumed that Senator Chris Coons had seen this interview because we brought him here to talk about DOGE yesterday and Social Security. But when I asked him if he had actually watched the real people who are doing this work and what they said about it, he didn't really give me answer. But here's what he did say about all of it.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. CHRIS COONS (D-DE): I've had senior folks from DOGE lie to my face about other federal agencies where they claim they have found widespread waste, fraud and abuse, where previous audits did not find that waste, fraud and abuse. Elon Musk says that Social Security is a Ponzi scheme and this President has fired the relevant inspectors general --

MACCALLUM: Yes.

COONS: -- who are the people most capable? Not a bunch of 20-year-old software engineers with no previous government experience.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACCALLUM: It's a little bit frustrating yesterday, but we did go back and ask his office again exactly what did they lie to you about to your face as he said, no response from them on that. We also pointed out that 71.8 billion in improper payments were paid out to Social Security.

What's your response when you hear that from this prominent Democrat senator?

BAIER: Well, good afternoon, Martha. I think first of all, politically, it's pretty tough to defend waste, fraud and abuse. You know, saying that you can't find it in the federal government. It is massive. Every inspector general has come up with some level and DOGE is digging in and finding exponentially more.

I don't think that the group that was with me is lying about what they're finding. I do think that they're putting up as transparently as they can on this website, and I think they're going to better in coming weeks about putting the receipts up there. But these aren't 20 year olds with hoodies digging into your Social Security data. These are accomplished either engineers or CEOs or founders of businesses like Airbnb. There are three billionaires in that room as I talked to them last week, including Elon.

And they're donating their time and seeing why these ancient computers can't talk to each other. And that is why the fraud is able to happen at the level it is, at least according to them.

MACCALLUM: Yes. It reminds me of, you know, after 911, we heard just how archaic so many of the systems were and how sclerotic all these bureaucracies were, even in our intel systems. And it shows up everywhere we look with the revelations in these different agencies, and where the money's going, and all of it. and how many people are showing up for work.

I thought that interview was really enlightening. And I do suggest that Senator Coons watch it because maybe he could come back and we could have a substantive conversation about it. With regard to Elon Musk, you asked him if he how long he's staying.

Yesterday all these this buzz was around, were all hearing it about maybe he's leaving earlier. What's your take on that?

BAIER: Yes. It was the first question I asked because there's a lot of questions about how much they can get done in the short time. And technically he's a special government employee, SGE, and that is 130 days. There's a stipulation that designation can only work 130 days inside an administration or tangential to one.

And he said within that time he believes That Doge will find the $1 trillion that its goal, and there will be more work to do. But he suggested that at the 130 days his job is going to be done. And I asked, you know, a number of different ways that question.

So when that story popped the other day, I thought, wow, this is kind of what he said. So maybe Politico or Axios didn't watch either.

MACCALLUM: Yes, maybe not. Yes, that would bring us, I guess, to May or June, 130 days- ish. Bret, thank you. Always good to see you.

BAIER: You, too.

MACCALLUM: We'll see you tonight.

BAIER: All right. So Michael Shellenberger on why Democrats are fighting President Trump's order to secure elections and what they don't like about that, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACCALLUM: So top Democrats on Capitol Hill suing President Trump over his executive order overhauling federal elections. That includes requiring proof of citizenship to register to vote.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. HAKEEM JEFFRIES (D-NY): We are challenging that unconstitutional, illegal executive order in court, and we are going to win. Donald Trump doesn't have the power to decide how federal elections are governed. That power is given to the voters, state legislatures, and Congress.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACCALLUM: So how about those voters? Democrats filed that lawsuit one day after 63 percent of voters in battleground Wisconsin approved a state constitutional amendment that would require that you got to show an ID if you're going to register to vote. With that, we bring in journalist Michael Shellenberger, founder of Public, who helped expose the Twitter files and what he calls the censorship industrial complex. Michael, always good to have you back.

Are Democrats out of step on this issue? Given the polling that has shown time and time again that the majority, vast majority of Americans are very much in favor of ID for voting?

MICHAEL SHELLENBERGER, JOURNALIST: Yes. Hey, great to be with you, Martha. I mean, again, we see Democrats have got themselves on the wrong side of a pretty popular issue. And particularly see that vote in Wisconsin I thought was pretty stunning, the margin of victory there.

It's just hard to argue in this day and age that you shouldn't be able to have a license, you shouldn't be required to show your license when we're so accustomed to showing it for so many other things in society. And so, Democrats find themselves not able to really make the argument against showing identification.

Every time they do, they end up finding themselves sort of putting down somebody, usually racial minorities, suggesting that they will discriminate against them because somehow they're less able to produce their ID. So I just think Democrats once again got themselves on the wrong side of an issue.

And an issue that whatever happens in the courts, Republicans can continue to underscore their commitment to national identity, which has been such a big part of Trump's appeal.

MACCALLUM: Yes. I mean, I've heard a lot of politicians, including Winsome Sears, say that she thinks it's insulting, to suggest that not everyone is able to procure some form of identification. And it, you know, put this up from the Wall Street Journal, 36 states have laws requiring or requesting voters to show some kind of ID.

According to the National Conference of State Legislatures, voter idea laws are one way to restore confidence in elections. Progressives may not like it, but it turns out to be a bipartisan winner with voters as you were saying.

I want to get your thought on this as well. Nicole Parker, former FBI agent, who our viewers see here quite a bit, got very emotional in recent testimony when she talked about FBI colleagues of hers who were killed in the line of duty while other FBI agents were spending all their time tracking down non-violent January 6th participants. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

NICOLE PARKER, FORMER FBI SPECIAL AGENT: February 2nd of 2021, FBI Miami Special Agent Laura Schwartzenberger and Daniel Alfin were shot and killed in the line of duty while executing a search warrant on a child predator. It is disturbing to me that during the same time frame, we regularly heard of FBI SWAT resources liberally being dispatched for the arrest of first time non-violent January 6 offenders.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACCALLUM: Do you think that they're that we're going to see a change in the priorities at the FBI, Michael?

SHELLENBERGER: Well, I think we've already seen them, right. We see Director Kash Patel and Deputy Director Bongino out there really emphasizing traditional crime, fighting against drug dealers, drug gangs, violent criminals. I think that's where Americans want to see that focus go.

And yes, I think as time goes on, we're going to really start to see more information come out about what exactly was going on January 6th and why did we put so much effort into prosecuting non-violent offenders. The hypocrisy there was, of course, we have Democrats for decades arguing that we had gone too hard on non-violent offenders and filled the prisons with people that shouldn't have been there.

Well, what were we doing dedicating all those Department of Justice resources, FBI resources, prosecutor resources, to going after grandmothers and people that just didn't even realize they were breaking the law in some cases. Just following the crowd into the Capitol, imagine that had somehow been permitted.

It was really a gross abuse of power, I think one of the worst that we saw over the last four years. So hopefully we'll see the FBI on the right track and start to also disclose all that information we're eager to get.

MACCALLUM: Absolutely. Michael, thank you very much. Michael Shellenberger joining us.

That is "The Story" for this Thursday, April 3rd. As always, "The Story" goes on. We'll see you back here tomorrow for a Friday at 3:00. Stay tuned, though, Will Cain get started right about now.

urn:contentItem:6D0P-7241-F03F-K17F-00000-00Brazil faces environmental terrorism amid criminal wildfires, minister says2024-09-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:25:37ZLexisNexisBrazil faces environmental terrorism amid criminal wildfires, minister says

Brazil is facing a “criminal alliance” exploiting the severe drought to promote “climate terrorism,” Environment Minister Marina Silva said on Tuesday. In an interview with CanalGov, she stated that the country is experiencing a “delicate situation,” with wildfires spreading in various regions. She advocated for harsher penalties for those who set fire to forests.

“At this moment, it is a delicate situation. This drought is happening in many places. In Bolivia, Peru, Paraguay, and other parts of the world, there are also fires,” Ms. Silva said. “The difference here in Brazil is that there is a criminal alliance, a kind of climate terrorism, where people are using climate change to worsen the problem. This is a crime against the public interest, against public finances. It is a crime that certainly deserves a more severe penalty.”

For Ms. Silva, there is in Brazil “a criminal alliance among political ideologies that want to deny the issue of climate change and the crime that is being committed persistently in all regions of the country.” She argued that these individuals “should be punished according to the law.”

Ms. Silva said that there is no evidence of fires caused by lightning, so all fires have been attributed to human action. She recalled that any forest fire is considered criminal throughout the country, due to the nationwide ban on using fire for agricultural purposes.

“Right now, any fire is characterized as a criminal fire. There is a ban on the use of fire across the entire national territory,” she said. “We are experiencing a severe drought practically across the entire country. And this ban means that any fire is in violation of the law. And that constitutes a crime.”

The wildfires in various regions of the country, with smoke directly affecting populations in major urban centers, are placing pressure on Minister Silva and the Lula administration as a whole.

President Lula convened an emergency meeting with the heads of the branches of government on Tuesday at the Palácio do Planalto to address the issue. By Monday evening, Chief Justice Luís Roberto Barroso, Lower House Speaker Arthur Lira, and Senate President Rodrigo Pacheco had confirmed their attendance. Ms. Silva noted that this indicates that it is a state problem, not just a government issue.

Among the measures considered by the government is the creation of a legal status for the climate emergency, “to support public actions,” Ms. Silva said.

The government also plans to announce a Climate Authority, which is still being designed by Mr. Lula and his aides, to formulate policies for mitigating and adapting to climate change in infrastructure and the economy.

(Essa publicação é parte integrante do jornal Valor Econômico e se sujeita aos termos de uso do site.)

urn:contentItem:6CH3-G6R1-F12F-F2PJ-00000-00YESO FIRE UPDATE: CREWS TRANSITION TO CONTAINMENT WORK2024-07-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:25:37ZLexisNexisYESO FIRE UPDATE: CREWS TRANSITION TO CONTAINMENT WORK

TAOS, N.M., July 16 -- The U.S. Department of Agriculture's U.S. Forest Service unit - Carson National Forest - issued the following press release:

Carson National Forest fire crews are on scene of the Mestenas Canyon Fire, named after the canyon its burning deep within. It's about 10 miles southwest of Dulce, N.M., on the Jicarilla Ranger District and two miles north of Highway 64.

The lightning-caused fire was first reported July 11 and has grown to 145 acres. Fire crews have been on scene since, monitoring and planning to use suppression action points. Efforts may include cutting line on the fire's edge or using backfire off existing roads to reduce fuels ahead of approaching flames.

"This fire is in a difficult location with steep, rocky terrain and snags throughout the canyon bottom," said Jicarilla District Ranger Jim Eaton. "The terrain makes escapes routes very difficult and with snags constantly falling, poses significant hazards to our firefighters."

Forecasted rainfall may slow or stop the fire's spread before reaching action point locations.

Observed fire behavior has ranged between low to moderate, fluctuating with winds.

The public can keep updated on the fire by visiting InciWeb or calling a public information officer at 505-216-6793. For any query with respect to this article or any other content requirement, please contact Editor at contentservices@htdigital.in

urn:contentItem:6861-JPV1-F12F-F4Y1-00000-00INTERNATIONAL PATENT: SICHUAN AEROSPACE LIAOYUAN SCIENCE & TECHNOLOGY CO., LTD FILES APPLICATION FOR "AIRDROP FOREST FIRE EXTINGUISHING BOMB"2023-05-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:25:37ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONAL PATENT: SICHUAN AEROSPACE LIAOYUAN SCIENCE & TECHNOLOGY CO., LTD FILES APPLICATION FOR "AIRDROP FOREST FIRE EXTINGUISHING BOMB"GENEVA

GENEVA, May 8 -- SICHUAN AEROSPACE LIAOYUAN SCIENCE & TECHNOLOGY CO., LTD (No.105 Yidu Middle Road, Longquanyi DistrictChengdu, Sichuan 610199) filed a patent application (PCT/CN2021/132440) for "AIRDROP FOREST FIRE EXTINGUISHING BOMB" on Nov 23, 2021. With publication no. WO/2023/070787, the details related to the patent application was published on May 04, 2023.

Notably, the patent application was submitted under the International Patent Classification (IPC) system, which is managed by the World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO). Inventor(s): GUO, Minhua (NO.105 Yidu Middle Road, Longquanyi DistrictChengdu, Sichuan 610199), HUANG, Weibo (NO.105 Yidu Middle Road, Longquanyi DistrictChengdu, Sichuan 610199), HE, Liwen (NO.105 Yidu Middle Road, Longquanyi DistrictChengdu, Sichuan 610199), TANG, Peng (NO.105 Yidu Middle Road, Longquanyi DistrictChengdu, Sichuan 610199), ZHANG, Zhenlin (NO.105 Yidu Middle Road, Longquanyi DistrictChengdu, Sichuan 610199), XIAO, Ruigang (NO.105 Yidu Middle Road, Longquanyi DistrictChengdu, Sichuan 610199), YAO, Xiang (NO.105 Yidu Middle Road, Longquanyi DistrictChengdu, Sichuan 610199), CHEN, Lingyun (NO.105 Yidu Middle Road, Longquanyi DistrictChengdu, Sichuan 610199), DONG, Wenye (NO.105 Yidu Middle Road, Longquanyi DistrictChengdu, Sichuan 610199), ZHANG, Xu (NO.105 Yidu Middle Road, Longquanyi DistrictChengdu, Sichuan 610199), GAO, Bixiang (NO.105 Yidu Middle Road, Longquanyi DistrictChengdu, Sichuan 610199), LI, Weijie (NO.105 Yidu Middle Road, Longquanyi DistrictChengdu, Sichuan 610199), HU, Ming (NO.105 Yidu Middle Road, Longquanyi DistrictChengdu, Sichuan 610199), XIANG, Wang (NO.105 Yidu Middle Road, Longquanyi DistrictChengdu, Sichuan 610199), CHEN, Yang (NO.105 Yidu Middle Road, Longquanyi DistrictChengdu, Sichuan 610199), MA, Baocheng (NO.105 Yidu Middle Road, Longquanyi DistrictChengdu, Sichuan 610199) Abstract: An airdrop forest fire extinguishing bomb is aerial firefighting equipment that is mainly loaded on an aerial platform such as a helicopter and an unmanned aerial vehicle, employs an airdrop launching mode, flies in an unpowered gliding mode, and implements high-precision forest fire extinguishing by means of guidance control. A three-section split structure is used, and a seeker cabin, an agent cabin, and a steering engine cabin are sequentially arranged from front to back; the seeker cabin is used for providing a mounting space for a head aerodynamic configuration and an infrared seeker; the agent cabin is used for loading a fire extinguishing agent; fins are fixed to the outer surface of the agent cabin; and the steering engine cabin is used for providing a mounting space for a steering engine and an avionics system and providing a control moment when a bomb body flies. The airdrop forest fire extinguishing bomb employs a throwing mode of a central detonation tube structure, and the fire extinguishing agent preloaded in the agent cabin is driven to be throwed to the periphery by means of explosion to form a certain area of coverage, thereby achieving a fire extinguishing effect. For more information:https://patentscope.wipo.int/search/en/detail.jsf?docId=WO2023070787 For any query with respect to this article or any other content requirement, please contact Editor at contentservices@htlive.com

urn:contentItem:67R4-N931-JBSP-1034-00000-00Research from Nanjing Forestry University in the Area of Algorithms Described (A Semi-Supervised Method for Real-Time Forest Fire Detection Algorithm Based on Adaptively Spatial Feature Fusion)2023-03-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:25:37ZLexisNexisALGORITHMSResearch from Nanjing Forestry University in the Area of Algorithms Described (A Semi-Supervised Method for Real-Time Forest Fire Detection Algorithm Based on Adaptively Spatial Feature Fusion)


2023 MAR 08 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Math Daily News -- Fresh data on algorithms are presented in a new report. According to news reporting from Nanjing, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "Forest fires occur frequently around the world, causing serious economic losses and human casualties. Deep learning techniques based on convolutional neural networks (CNN) are widely used in the intelligent detection of forest fires. However, CNN-based forest fire target detection models lack global modeling capabilities and cannot fully extract global and contextual information about forest fire targets."


Funders for this research include Key Research And Development Plan of Jiangsu Province; Jiangsu Modern Agricultural Machinery Equipment And Technology Demonstration And Promotion Project; Nanjing Modern Agricultural Machinery Equipment And Technological Innovation Demonstration Projects; National Natural Science Foundation of China; Jiangsu Postdoctoral Research Foundation.
Our news reporters obtained a quote from the research from Nanjing Forestry University: "CNNs also pay insufficient attention to forest fires and are vulnerable to the interference of invalid features similar to forest fires, resulting in low accuracy of fire detection. In addition, CNN-based forest fire target detection models require a large number of labeled datasets. Manual annotation is often used to annotate the huge amount of forest fire datasets; however, this takes a lot of time. To address these problems, this paper proposes a forest fire detection model, TCA-YOLO, with YOLOv5 as the basic framework. Firstly, we combine the Transformer encoder with its powerful global modeling capability and self-attention mechanism with CNN as a feature extraction network to enhance the extraction of global information on forest fire targets. Secondly, in order to enhance the model's focus on forest fire targets, we integrate the Coordinate Attention (CA) mechanism. CA not only acquires inter-channel information but also considers direction-related location information, which helps the model to better locate and identify forest fire targets. Integrated adaptively spatial feature fusion (ASFF) technology allows the model to automatically filter out useless information from other layers and efficiently fuse features to suppress the interference of complex backgrounds in the forest area for detection. Finally, semi-supervised learning is used to save a large amount of manual labeling effort. The experimental results show that the average accuracy of TCA-YOLO improves by 5.3 compared with the unimproved YOLOv5. TCA-YOLO also outperformed in detecting forest fire targets in different scenarios. The ability of TCA-YOLO to extract global information on forest fire targets was much improved. Additionally, it could locate forest fire targets more accurately."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "TCA-YOLO misses fewer forest fire targets and is less likely to be interfered with by forest fire-like targets. TCA-YOLO is also more focused on forest fire targets and better at small-target forest fire detection. FPS reaches 53.7, which means that the detection speed meets the requirements of real-time forest fire detection."
For more information on this research see: A Semi-Supervised Method for Real-Time Forest Fire Detection Algorithm Based on Adaptively Spatial Feature Fusion. Forests, 2023,14(2). (Forests - http://www.mdpi.com/journal/forests/). The publisher for Forests is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/f14020361.
Our news journalists report that more information may be obtained by contacting Ji Lin, College of Information Science and Technology, Nanjing Forestry University, Nanjing 210037, People's Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Haifeng Lin, Fang Wang.
ORCID is an identifier for authors and includes bibliographic information. The following is ORCID information for the authors of this research: Ji Lin (orcid.org/0000-0002-5102-3128), Haifeng Lin (orcid.org/0000-0002-3835-6075).
Keywords for this news article include: Nanjing Forestry University, Nanjing, People's Republic of China, Asia, Algorithms.

urn:contentItem:6D7H-C1J1-DY8S-B4BC-00000-00Look Back: Four miners saved, four killed in 1931 Mocanaqua coal mine explosion2024-10-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:25:37ZLexisNexisSTATE AND REGIONAL NEWSLook Back: Four miners saved, four killed in 1931 Mocanaqua coal mine explosionEd LewisThe Times Leader, Wilkes-Barre, Pa.

Oct. 20—Rescuers worked night and day for six consecutive days to reach six entombed miners in the East drift of the Red Ash vein of the West End Coal Co. mine in Mocanaqua during the last week of October 1931.

A gas explosion dropped hundreds of tons of coal and rock into a coal seam opening about 2,000 feet below the surface and 500 feet from the face of the gangway late Saturday night on Oct. 26, 1931. Two miners, Gabriel Skviak, 45, and John Tagmani, 35, both of Mocanaqua, were immediately pulled from the doomed mine and taken to Nanticoke State Hospital for severe burns to their faces, hands and arms.

There was hope steel timbers that replaced aging and rotting wood timbers survived the blast, creating pockets in the coal seam where it was believed the entombed miners took refuge.

"Several years ago, West End Coal Co. installed steel girders instead of wooden timbers in certain sections of the caved area. If these were not shattered, opinion was expressed that rapid progress would be made during the night in reaching the men," reported the Wilkes-Barre Record on Oct. 26, 1931.

Families of the entombed miners and hundreds of anxious relatives gathered at the site on the wind-blown mountainside while rescue squads worked feverishly to determine if the men were alive or dead. Several of those who gathered prayed out loud while holding candles.

Three rescue crews each with 30 men worked eight hour shifts.

As efforts to reach the trapped miners continued, a forest fire erupted nearby on the mountainside that was battled by two of the three rescue crews during their rest period.

"Company officials said that crews are working from two directions; that good progress was being made but that they had no idea how close the rescue squads might be to the spot where the men are believed to have been trapped," the Record reported Oct. 29, 1931.

Rescue crews finally reached the six men, finding two survived and four were killed, just before 6 a.m. on Oct. 30, 1931.

John Tomashunis, 40, of Shickshinny, father of seven children, and John Motzoni, 22, of Mocanaqua, were lifted from their mine prison and taken to Nanticoke State Hospital.

"While relatives and friends of Tomashunis and Motzoni were rejoicing, sorrow reigned in four other homes. Bodies of the dead were taken to their homes for funerals," the Record reported Oct. 31, 1931.

John Molitoris, 35, Jacob Tinus, 45, Henry Ceglarski, and Paul Novak, 40, all from Mocanaqua, were identified as those killed.

The Record reported Tinus and Novak were killed in the gas explosion while Molitoris and Ceglarski were overcome by poisonous black damp.

"Business was suspended and Mocanaqua streets were crowded for the four men as their caskets were carried from their respective homes and placed on hearse," the Record reported of their funerals.

Molitoris, Novak and Tinus had their funeral mass at the Slovak Church of Ascension while Ceglarski's funeral mass was held at St. Mary's Polish Church.

"On leaving the churches, the funerals again merged for the walk to the cemeteries. Novak, Tinus and Molitoris were interred in adjacent graves in the Slovak cemetery while Ceglarski was buried in the adjoining Polish cemetery," the Record reported.
